context: Even without the contribution of fungal hyphae, flat fungal biofilms supported ECs one order of magnitude larger than the 12 g m−3 h−1 reported by Dupasquier et al. (2002), during n-pentane biodegradation in a biofilter inoculated with Pseudomonas aeruginosa at 30 °C co-metabolically degrading methyl tert-butyl ether (MTBE). Therefore, based on the low fungal growth during stage II (visual observation), it can be concluded that the aerial biomass was responsible for at least 71.6(±4)% of the EC in the bioreactor during stage I. This finding can be explained by the large surface area provided by the aerial fungal hyphae together with the occurrence of hydrophobic proteins on their surface triggered as a response to the presence of a hydrophobic carbon source such as n-pentane (Vergara-Fernández et al., 2011a). At the end of the experiment, the biomass present in the solid support (non-aerial biomass) was 60.3(±5.8) gmonolayer biomass L−1 dry support. Finally, the mineralization of n-pentane during stage II accounted for 69.2(±7.3)%,

The presence of hydrophobic proteins on fungal hyphae is also noted, which are triggered by the hydrophobic nature of pentane, further emphasizing the connection between pentane and carbon in the context of biodegradation.
